title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SAN ANTONIO (AP) — They came to witness a coronation, and David Robinson did not disappoint. In a virtuoso performance for the ages, the Admiral single-handedly steered the San Antonio Spurs to a commanding 96-76 victory over the Sacramento Kings, turning a routine regular-season contest into a personal showcase of historic proportions.

Robinson was simply unstoppable, pouring in a career-high and franchise-record 61 points. From the opening tip, he established his dominance in the paint, a force of nature the Kings had no answer for. His 22 made field goals were a testament to an unstoppable offensive repertoire, while his 17-for-20 performance from the free-throw line punished Sacramento for every desperate foul. He didn’t just score; he controlled the entire game, completing a monstrous double-double with 16 rebounds.

While Robinson’s offensive explosion rightfully commands the headlines, the Spurs’ defensive effort was equally pivotal. Sacramento’s leading scorer, Mitch Richmond, was held to a mere 12 points, a paltry sum against Robinson’s tidal wave of production. The Kings, as a team, were smothered, shooting a frigid 35 percent from the field.

On this night, the Alamodome was Robinson’s domain. Every other statline—Sean Elliott’s 15 points, Richmond’s quiet 12—became a mere footnote. This was not merely a win; it was a historic statement, a 61-point masterpiece etched into the annals of Spurs lore, a performance so dominant it rendered the final score a mere formality.
